sections.title: Improvi\b\t q\fality models for MT eval\fatio\b based o\b eval\fators’ feedback Pa\fla Estrella
, Ma\thi Ki\b\t
paragraphs: ISSCO/\bI\t/E\bI, \fniversity of Geneva 40, bd. du Pont-d’Arve 1211 Geneva, Switzerland 2 IDIAP Research Institute Av. des Prés-Beudin 20 1920 \tartigny, Switzerland

E-mail: paula.estrella@issco.unige.ch, andrei.popescu-belis@idiap.ch, maghi.king@gmail.com Abstract \bhe Framework for the Evaluation for \tachine \branslation (FE\t\bI) contains guidelines for building a quality model that is used to evaluate \t\b systems in relation to the purpose and intended context of use of the systems. Contextual quality models can thus be constructed, but entering into FE\t\bI the knowledge required for this operation is a complex task. An experiment has been set up in order to transfer knowledge from \t\b evaluation experts into the FE\t\bI guidelines, by polling experts about the evaluation methods they would use in a particular context, then inferring from the results generic relations between characteristics of the context of use and quality characteristics. \bhe results of this hands-on exercise, carried out as part of a conference tutorial, have served to refine FE\t\bI’s ‘generic contextual quality model’ and to obtain feedback on the FE\t\bI guidelines in general.

sections.title: 1. I\btrod\fctio\b
paragraphs: \bhe Framework for the Evaluation of \tachine \branslation (FE\t\bI) was introduced by the ISLE Evaluation Working Group, as an implementation of the EAGLES evaluation guidelines in the case of \t\b systems. \bhe guidelines help evaluators to define quality models used to evaluate \t\b systems, based on the purpose and intended context of use of the systems (Hovy et al. 2002, King et al. 2003). \bhe FE\t\bI framework is publicly available and benefits from user-friendly interfaces that guide evaluators with the definition of quality models and the selection of metrics (http://www.issco.unige.ch/femti/). In this paper, we report results from an experiment aimed at transferring knowledge from \t\b evaluation experts into the FE\t\bI guidelines. After a brief reminder of FE\t\bI’s main features (Section 2), we demonstrate their relevance by relating them to two recent examples of contextualized evaluation of \t\b systems, for real-world uses (Section 3). \bhe conditions of the hands-on \t\b evaluation exercise are outlined in Section 4, while the method for transforming the experts’ output into FE\t\bI knowledge and the results obtained with this approach are described in Section 5. Section 6 shows the integration of results into the FE\t\bI framework, while some conclusions and future work are outlined in Section 7.

sections.title: 2. Eval\fatio\b of MT Systems i\b Co\btext 2.1. FEMTI Compo\be\bts
paragraphs: FE\t\bI is made up of three components: the first one (‘Part I’) is a classification of possible user requirements or, more generally, of contexts\b o\t\b use of an \t\b system. \bherefore, FE\t\bI Part I classifies the characteristics concerning the tas\f to be performed by the \t\b system, the author and text\btype of the input to the system, and the type\b o\t\buser of the system. \bhe second component of FE\t\bI (‘Part II’) is a classification of quality characteristics based on the general ones first defined in the ISO/IEC 9126-1 standard for software evaluation (ISO/IEC 1991, 2001). \bhe six top level characteristics of FE\t\bI Part II are the ISO ones, namely \tunctionality, reliability, usability, e\t\ticiency, maintainability and portability, plus an extra characteristic, namely cost. Each top level characteristic is further decomposed into a hierarchy of characteristics which are specific to \t\b systems, and human and/or automatic metrics are attached to each node of this hierarchy, which can be used to evaluate the corresponding feature of the system, i.e. a quality attribute. \bhe third component of FE\t\bI is the linking mechanism between Part I and Part II described in the next section.

sections.title: 2.2. Li\bki\b\t Mecha\bism
paragraphs: \bhe generation of evaluation plans is based on particular quality models, which are subsets of the FE\t\bI Part II repertoire of quality characteristics and metrics. \bo extract such a subset, evaluators define first the requirements for the system (Part I), then apply a mechanism that uses the relations between each user requirement and the relevant quality characteristics of the system to be evaluated to construct the quality model. \bherefore, the influence of the intended context of use on the quality model is represented formally as a matrix, called a generic\b contextual\b quality\b model or GCQ\t (Popescu-Belis et al. 2006). Each row of the FE\t\bI GCQ\t represents a quality characteristic of Part II, and each column is a context characteristic from Part I. (For efficiency and readability, only those items from Parts I and II – context/quality characteristics – that have a connection or relation with one or more items are

represented in the actually implementation of the GCQ\t.) \bhe fact that a specific context characteristic requires the evaluation of a specific quality is represented as a relation or lin\f\bbetween\bone\bitem\bin\bPart\bI\band\banother\bitem\bin\bPart\b II. In the matrix representation of the GCQ\t, a link is represented by a weight in the corresponding cell indicating the importance of the link.  C10 C12 C35 C40 Q1 \b/a Q12 1 \b/a Q13 2

has the highest connection to quality Q24  \bhe scale used for the weights is: 1 (low importance), 2 (medium importance), 3 (high importance) or \b/a, which indicates the presence of a link with no specific weight (this allows backwards compatibility with the first version of FE\t\bI, which did not use weighted links). For example, context C10 is linked to quality Q24 indicated by a non-zero value and the weight of the link is 3, as shown in Figure 1. When an evaluator specifies a context of use with FE\t\bI, the FE\t\bI software represents the selected characteristics as a context vector, which is used internally to retrieve relevant quality characteristics from Part II that should be evaluated for that context of use. \bhis process thus generates a\b quality\b vector\bby computing the matrix product of the context vector and of the GCQ\t matrix.

sections.title: 2.3. A\ftomati\b\t the Ge\beratio\b of Q\fality Models with FEMTI
paragraphs: Recent work on FE\t\bI was devoted to develop new web-based interfaces as well as to define and implement an automatic tool that provides suggestions for relating contexts of use to quality characteristics, as described formally in the previous section (Estrella et al. 2005). \bhere are two interfaces to the framework, one for evaluators and one for experts. \bhe evaluators’ interface helps to generate \t\b evaluation plans based on a given context of use, offering significant improvement in terms of automation over the first version of FE\t\bI. \bhe interface for experts is intended to help experts define the links in the GCQ\t between items in Part I and items in Part II, based on their own implicit knowledge of relevant quality characteristics, or on experience from previous evaluations. Experts can assign weights on the links as mentioned above, including the ‘n/a’ mention if a relation is hypothesized but its precise strength is not apparent to them (many links imported from the initial version of FE\t\bI are currently marked with ‘n/a’). \bhe two interfaces to FE\t\bI are tightly related, since it is through the experts’ interface that GCQ\ts are created, but it is in the evaluators interface that an averaged GCQ\t combining those created by experts is used. In the evaluators’ interface, once an evaluator defines an intended context of use (represented internally as a vector), the scripts implementing the linking mechanism described in the previous section retrieve relevant links from the averaged\bGCQ\t and compute the relevant quality characteristics from Part II, which are highlighted by the interface. \bhe last step in building a customized quality model consists of selecting the actual quality characteristics that will be evaluated among those proposed by FE\t\bI, and finally the corresponding metrics to measure them.

sections.title: 3. Two Rece\bt Examples of Co\btext\fal MT Eval\fatio\b
paragraphs: Evaluation of \t\b systems is a complex task to normalize, even with a user-friendly interface that automatically suggests relevant quality for an intended context of use. For many \t\b developers, evaluation remains a matter of measuring the “quality” of output text using reference-based metrics such as BLE\f or human-based metrics such as accuracy/fluency. However, when evaluating software dedicated to real-life commercial applications, context-based evaluation cannot be avoided if optimal choices have to be made for large organizations, as the two following case studies show. GPHIN is a multilingual Internet-based early warning system that gathers preliminary reports with potential public-health significance on a nearly real-time basis (Blench 2007). GPHIN continuously gathers and disseminates multilingual information from newswire and web sites, which requires several \t\b sub-systems or ‘engines’, which were carefully selected to ensure the success of the system as a whole. \bhe requirements for these engines are very strict, given the mode of operation of GPHIN. In consequence, a list of important qualities that determine whether or not to incorporate a new \t\b engine into the system was defined, which includes robustness, high interoperability and ease of dictionary update. Robustness is a critical aspect, and no actual engine passed the stress tests, so a special module was developed to fix this issue. \bhe GPHIN system proved to be very productive in monitoring and efficient in early detection of outbreaks, the most relevant case being the detection of a SARS outbreak almost three months in advance. From an even more systematic perspective close to FE\t\bI, Stadler and Peter-Spörndli (2007) present a quality model developed for \t\b systems to be used by a translation service provider, which was based on the ISO definition for quality and on the premise that different types of customers have different needs. \bhe main quality attributes in this model were extracted from user feedback and include translation quality, usability, actual translation directions and supported file formats. \bhis work shows many similarities to the FE\t\bI context-based approach to evaluation; in particular, as the selected quality attributes are present in FE\t\bI, this model is fully compatible with FE\t\bI provided the same terminology for quality
characteristics is used. Ideally, the same quality model could be obtained using FE\t\bI, by entering the respective context characteristics, if the current GCQ\t was completely populated with links.

sections.title: 4. Ma\b\fally Relati\b\t Co\btexts of Use a\bd Q\fality Models
paragraphs: \bhe topics and tools related to context-based evaluation constituted the basis of a tutorial offered as part of the \tachine \branslation Summit XI. \bhe objective was not only to introduce the tools to potential users, but also to obtain input from them, based on their previous evaluation experience, in order to improve FE\t\bI by enriching its GCQ\t with more links between Parts I and II.

sections.title: 4.1. Si\t\bifica\bce of the Experime\bt
paragraphs: In the current state, FE\t\bI is a valuable source of knowledge about \t\b evaluation, and the evaluation plans generated with it have the potential to be used as a starting point for a true evaluation. However, users of FE\t\bI with less experience in \t\b evaluation might need some guidance for the generation of evaluation plans, for example about the quality characteristics of the system he/she would like to evaluate. Part of such guidance could be provided by the links in FE\t\bI’s GCQ\t. Populating links in the GCQ\t is a hard and demanding effort, given the large size of the GCQ\t and the fact that these links should be validated by several \t\b experts. \bherefore, the purpose of the experiment presented in this paper is to enrich the current GCQ\t by generating more links based on experts’ knowledge and experience.

sections.title: 4.2. Descriptio\b of the Elicitatio\b Exercise
paragraphs: \bhe goal was to create one GCQ\t for a specific scenario, based on the participants’ experience with \t\b system. Part of the tutorial was indeed devoted to the practical activity, which consisted of the following steps:

For practical reasons, the participants to the tutorial could not use the web-based experts’ interface, but a printed compilation of FE\t\bI’s content was prepared to their intent. Participants were arranged in four groups of about four persons and focused only on a small subset of context and quality characteristics, due to time constraints. \bhe results of each group were summarized by the organizers during a break, and then discussed at the end of the tutorial; these results are presented in the following section. sections.title: 5. Res\flts of the Experime\bt
paragraphs: \bhe scenario of use (Figure 2) was defined as a compromise between precision and generality: indeed, participants needed a reasonably clear scenario of \t\b use to define evaluation methods, but this scenario had to be general enough to avoid biasing the participants towards any specific context/quality characteristics. We expected to see some overlap across groups in the answers, i.e. that most or some of the groups would use the same elementary context characteristics to define the scenario, and that they would relate them to the same quality characteristics. \bo illustrate the outcome of the exercise, the result of one of the groups – context characteristics and related quality characteristics with their weights – is shown in \bable 1. However, it appeared that each group interpreted the scenario in a slightly different manner, choosing different elementary context characteristics to define the translation task of the \t\b system. \bhe groups agreed on the top level context characteristic, ‘assimilation’, but when further specifying the task, each group interestingly chose a different sub-task: ‘search’ vs. ‘information extraction’ vs. ‘document routing/sorting’ (the fourth group did not specify the task any further). \bhe diverging choice of the exact specification of the translation task then made groups focus also on different relevant qualities, though You have a contract with the International Olympic Committee to track what is said in the Chinese press about the preparations for the Olympic Games in China. You do not read Chinese, but you do have a limited budget for translation. You think you may be able to use an \t\b system to select relevant articles, which you will then get translated by humans. What system characteristics are relevant? Which

quite close to each other, leading in the end to the creation of different GCQ\ts for each group. (It is, of course, reasonable to design specific evaluation plans for systems intended to perform different tasks.) In addition, it is worth noting that the contexts of use that were defined not only focused on the translation task, but also included other important items such as the user of the \t\b system, thus suggesting that FE\t\bI offers indeed a richer methodology for evaluation. In the answers obtained from the four expert groups participating in these experiments, several context characteristics were shared by more than one group, independently of the exact translation task chosen by the groups, suggesting that for scenarios similar to the one proposed in Figure 2, the following context characteristics are of significant interest for an evaluation:

We also expected links (relations between context and quality characteristics) to reach a significant number of terminal nodes in Part II, i.e. the measurable attributes. Indeed, if most of the context characteristics were linked to only one quality characteristic, this would mean that the context has no longer an impact on evaluation and assessing that single quality characteristic would always be enough, which is not the case for real-world systems, as illustrated above. In our experiment, we observed a diversity of answers, due to the different contexts defined in the first place. However, a series of quality characteristics appear to be important for the given scenario, such as \tidelity, terminology, dictionaries, input\b to\boutput\btranslation\bspeed and cost. \bhe results of the exercise – i.e. the context characteristics, quality characteristics, and weighted links – were summarized at the end of the tutorial in a table representing the GCQ\t jointly generated by the experts, as shown in Figure 3. \bhe groups were numbered from 1 to 4 (first figure in each table cell) and the numbers 1–3 in parenthesis denote the relevance of each relation assigned by each group; no number between parenthesis means that there is a link but no weight was assigned, as explained in Section 2.2. An example is shown in Figure 3, where some of the results from \bable 1 transferred to the GCQ\t are marked with dashed boxes, e.g. the translation task is document\brouting\b(1.2.1.1)\band it is related to terminology\b (2.1.1.1), assigning a score of 3 for the importance of this relation.

sections.title: 6. Co\btrib\ftio\b to FEMTI
paragraphs: From this hands-on exercise, around 40 new links were added to FE\t\bI’s GCQ\t. Although these changes and the whole mechanism behind FE\t\bI’s interfaces are transparent to the user, once the links are sufficiently populated, the resulting behavior of the FE\t\bI interface is that many more quality characteristics get suggested once context characteristics are specified. Another interesting aspect of introducing more links is that weights on links are considered for the final quality model to rank the quality characteristics according to their importance, that is, if many of the selected context characteristics point to the same quality characteristic, this one becomes more important to the evaluation and will appear higher in the list of quality characteristics to assess. Figure 4 illustrates the integration of these results into the current version of FE\t\bI; the qualities highlighted in Part II (right-hand side) come from links previously present in the GCQ\t plus the new links when selecting the context of \bable 1.

sections.title: 7. Co\bcl\fsio\b a\bd F\ft\fre Work
paragraphs: \bhrough the tutorial offered as part of the \tachine \branslation Summit XI, we were able to gather valuable feedback from \t\b users and evaluators, as well as to continue the integration of expertise into FE\t\bI. We believe that continuing such hands-on exercises is an important part of FE\t\bI development, and will organize a new tutorial at LREC 2008. \bhe results obtained with the 2007 practical exercise were incorporated to the existing GCQ\t in FE\t\bI, as they are part of the contribution to FE\t\bI by the \t\b community and should be available to the general public.

We intend to carry out larger scale experiments in the future, to populate relations between Parts I and II of FE\t\bI, as well as to identify areas of improvement for each of the two parts, possibly reorganizing the classifications or including new qualities or metrics. Another intended activity is to generate templates or typical use cases of FE\t\bI to facilitate its application to real-world scenarios, again based on input from \t\b experts.
